column1: At Hugbert's death (735) the duchy passed to a distant relative named Odilo

column1: Tassilo III (b. 741 – d. after 796) succeeded his father at the age of eight after an unsuccessful attempt by Grifo to rule Bavaria. He initially ruled under Frankish oversight but began to function independently from 763 onward. He was particularly noted for founding new monasteries and for expanding eastwards

column4: his cousin Charlemagne began to pressure Tassilo to submit and finally deposed him in 788. The deposition was not entirely legitimate. Dissenters attempted a coup against Charlemagne at Tassilo's old capital of Regensburg in 792

column7: this was the end of the Agilolfing dynasty.

column1: The geographic center of the European Union is located in the northwestern corner of Bavaria.
The summer months have been getting hotter in recent years. For example
column2: June 2019 was the warmest June in Bavaria since weather observations have been recorded and the winter 2019/2020 was 3 degrees Celsius warmer than the average temperature for many years all over Bavaria. On 20 December 2019 a record temperature of 20.2 °C (68.4 °F) was recorded in Piding. In general winter months are seeing more precipitation which is taking the form of rain more often than that of snow compared to the past. Extreme weather like the 2013 European floods or the 2019 European heavy snowfalls is occurring more and more often. One effect of the continuing warming is the melting of almost all Bavarian Alpine glaciers: Of the five glaciers of Bavaria only the Höllentalferner is predicted to exist over a longer time perspective. The Südliche Schneeferner has almost vanished since the 1980s.

Bavaria has a multiparty system dominated by the conservative Christian Social Union (CSU)
column2: which has won every election since 1945
column4: which became the second biggest political party in the 2018 parliament elections and the center-left Social Democrats (SPD)
column5: which dominates in Munich. Thus far Wilhelm Hoegner has been the only SPD candidate to ever become Minister-President; notable successors in office include multi-term Federal Minister Franz Josef Strauss
column6: a key figure among West German conservatives during the Cold War years
column8: who both failed with their bids for Chancellorship. The German Greens and the center-right Free Voters have been represented in the state parliament since 1986 and 2008 respectively.

column1: In the 2003 elections the CSU won a ⅔ supermajority – something no party had ever achieved in postwar Germany. However
column2: in the subsequent 2008 elections the CSU lost the absolute majority for the first time in 46 years. The losses were partly attributed by some to the CSU's stance for an anti-smoking bill. (A first anti-smoking law had been proposed by the CSU and passed but was watered down after the election
column3: after which a referendum enforced a strict antismoking bill with a large majority).

column1: The last state elections were held on 14 October 2018 in which the CSU lost its absolute majority in the state parliament in part due to the party's stances as part of the federal government
column2: winning 37.2% of the vote; the party's second worst election outcome in its history. The Greens who had surged in the polls leading up to the election have replaced the social-democratic SPD as the second biggest force in the Landtag with 17.5% of the vote. The SPD lost over half of its previous share compared to 2013 with a mere 9.7% in 2018. The liberals of the FDP were again able to reach the five-percent-threshold in order to receive mandates in parliament after they were not part of the Landtag after the 2013 elections. Also entering the new parliament will be the right-wing populist Alternative for Germany (AfD) with 10.2% of the vote. The center-right Free Voters party gained 11.6% of the vote and formed a government coalition with the CSU which lead to the subsequent reelection of Markus Söder as Minister-President of Bavaria.

column1: In 1995 Bavaria introduced direct democracy on the local level in a referendum. This was initiated bottom-up by an association called Mehr Demokratie (English: More Democracy). This is a grass-roots organization which campaigns for the right to citizen-initiated referendums. In 1997 the Bavarian Supreme Court tightened the regulations considerably (including by introducing a turn-out quorum). Nevertheless
column2: Bavaria has the most advanced regulations on local direct democracy in Germany. This has led to a spirited citizens' participation in communal and municipal affairs—835 referenda took place from 1995 through 2005.

column1: Bavaria has long had one of the largest economies of any region in Germany
column2: and in Europe. Its GDP in 2007 exceeded €434 billion (about U.S. $600 billion). This makes Bavaria itself one of the largest economies in Europe
column3: and only 20 countries in the world have a higher GDP. The Gross domestic product (GDP) of the region was €617.1 billion in 2018
column4: accounting for 18.5% of German economic output. GDP per capita adjusted for purchasing power was €43
column5: 500 or 144% of the EU27 average in the same year. The GDP per employee was 114% of the EU average. This makes Bavaria one of the wealthiest regions in Europe. Bavaria has strong economic ties with Austria

column1: Bavarian culture (Altbayern) has a long and predominant tradition of Catholic faith. Pope emeritus Benedict XVI (Joseph Alois Ratzinger) was born in Marktl am Inn in Upper Bavaria and was Cardinal-Archbishop of Munich and Freising. Otherwise
column2: the culturally Franconian and Swabian regions of the modern State of Bavaria are historically more diverse in religiosity
column3: with both Catholic and Protestant traditions. In 1925

column5: 28.8% was Protestant
column7: and 0.5% was placed in other religious categories.As of 2018 48.8% of Bavarians adhered to Catholicism (a decline from 70.4% in 1970). 17.9% of the population adheres to the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Bavaria
column8: which has also declined since 1970. 3% was Orthodox
column9: Muslims make up 4.0% of the population of Bavaria. 28.1% of Bavarians are irreligious or adhere to other religions.

column2: or Maypole (which in the Middle Ages served as the community's business directory

column1: Bavarians tend to place a great value on food and drink. In addition to their renowned dishes
column2: Bavarians also consume many items of food and drink which are unusual elsewhere in Germany; for example Weißwurst ("white sausage") or in some instances a variety of entrails. At folk festivals and in many beer gardens
column3: beer is traditionally served by the litre (in a Maß). Bavarians are particularly proud of the traditional Reinheitsgebot
column5: initially established by the Duke of Bavaria for the City of Munich (i.e. the court) in 1487 and the duchy in 1516. According to this law
column6: only three ingredients were allowed in beer: water
column8: and hops. In 1906 the Reinheitsgebot made its way to all-German law
column9: and remained a law in Germany until the EU partly struck it down in 1987 as incompatible with the European common market. German breweries
column12: and Bavarian breweries still comply with it in order to distinguish their beer brands. Bavarians are also known as some of the world's most beer-loving people with an average annual consumption of 170 liters per person
column13: although figures have been declining in recent years.

column5: Thuringian dialect is spoken. During the 20th century an increasing part of the population began to speak Standard German (Hochdeutsch)

column1: Bavarians consider themselves to be egalitarian and informal. Their sociability can be experienced at the annual Oktoberfest
column2: the world's largest beer festival
column3: which welcomes around six million visitors every year
column4: or in the famous beer gardens. In traditional Bavarian beer gardens
column5: patrons may bring their own food but buy beer only from the brewery that runs the beer garden.In the United States
column7: Bavarian culture is viewed somewhat nostalgically
column8: and several "Bavarian villages" have been founded
column13: the latter has been styled with a Bavarian theme and is home to an Oktoberfest celebration it claims is among the most attended in the world outside of Munich.

column1: Bavaria is home to several football clubs including FC Bayern Munich
column2: 1. FC Nürnberg
column5: FC Ingolstadt 04 and SpVgg Greuther Fürth. Bayern Munich is the most successful football team in Germany having won a record 30 German titles and 6 UEFA Champions League titles. They are followed by 1. FC Nürnberg who have won 9 titles. SpVgg Greuther Fürth have won 3 championships while TSV 1860 Munich have been champions once.

column1: Bavaria is also home to several professional basketball teams
column2: including s.Oliver Würzburg
column3: Nürnberg Falcons BC and TSV Oberhaching Tropics.

column1: There are five Bavarian ice hockey teams playing in the German top-tier league DEL: EHC Red Bull München
column2: Nürnberg Ice Tigers
column5: and Straubing Tigers.
